Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Structural Identification & Health Monitoring using Temperature-Driven Data

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The deteriorating state of bridges in the United States has become a societal issue.. The confluence of a debilitated bridge population nearing the end of its design life with a shortfall of funding has led to an unsustainable position. A paradigm aimed to address this issue is termed structural health monitoring, which is the practice of identifying and tracking performance of a structure by measured data and analytical simulation. The intended use of measured data is to optimize maintenance activities and increase safety of the users, thus reducing the costs of repairs and improving sustainability of the infrastructure. The static and dynamic approaches researched thus far have yet to reliably achieve all four levels established for successful health monitoring: detection, localization, extent and prognosis of structural impairment. This project pursues fundamental research for a novel approach that uses temperature related data for monitoring health of constructed systems. The project has advantage in its simplicity of measuring temperature. The method will target all four levels of monitoring aiming to impact bridges as well as potentially other structures. The project includes an outreach component for dissemination of findings to the engineering community and incorporating concepts into engineering education.

The goal of this project is to pursue development, validation and dissemination of a novel temperature-driven approach for evaluation and monitoring of health of constructed structural systems. In current techniques temperature effects are considered undesirable; the proposed method represents a change in paradigm - the temperature influences will be used to assess the structure. The new concept is based on the hypothesis that temperature variations can be treated as a forcing function and thus be used to obtain a complete input-output relationship (or transfer function). Research and identification of this temperature-driven transfer function is the main scientific contribution targeted for the study. To accomplish this objective a research plan is devised which includes framework development, laboratory/field experimentation and validation. The key advantages of the temperature-driven concept are applicability to non-linear systems, high signal-to-noise ratio, and reduced data management and time synchronization needs. In addition, the performance of many critical structural components is highly sensitive to temperature variations allowing for accurate and reliable identification and/or monitoring. Consequently, the temperature-driven concept has transformational potential since it will bring new knowledge in structural health monitoring.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The structural systems of majority of bridges in the U.S. are composed of beams. Approximately 60% of the U.S. bridges are beam-like structures with various types of cross-sections and materials. These typical bridges yield approximately 70% of all deficient bridges in the U.S.

Knowledge on true structural behavior, health condition and performance of bridges are crucial for effective, efficient, and economical preservation and maintenance actions. Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) aims to provide this knowledge, but is seldom applied in real life due to challenges in performance of current SHM methods.

The overall objective of this research is to create, validate, and disseminate a novel, temperature driven (TD) concept for health and performance assessment of bridges (TD-SHM). This concept is based on the fact that temperature changes can be treated as an actually measurable input for bridges, and consequently they can be used to generate a complete input-output relationship, also called 'transfer function'.

The transfer function, when plotted in 3D as a diagram creates so-called 3D signature, can be used to assess structural health and performance of the structure. This novel concept represents transformative departure from current SHM approaches, where the temperature influences are considered as undesirable noise that is filtered out.

The concept proposes to take advantage of large thermally generated outputs (strain, displacements, etc.) and use them to assess structural health and performance of the structure.

The following specific objectives were achieved: (a) Establishment of temperature intervals for steady-state data and the minimum data required; this was necessary to identify sources of uncertainties and evaluate their magnitudes as related to identification of various parameters needed for TD-SHM; (b) Establishment of parameters to be used in 3D signatures - generalized strain, generalized temperature and generalized displacement; it was necessary to identify combinations that provide effective solutions; (c) Establishment of algorithms for creation of 3D signatures; this objective is direct follow-up of objective (b) and targets the main parameters of the signatures such as shape, domain, etc.; (d) Establishment of threshold criteria for reliable detection of unusual structural behavior; this objective practically integrates outcomes (a)-(c) into the method; (e) Creation of Framework for TD-SHM and associated guidelines.

In addition two more methods, that were not originally planned, were created: (i) universal method for validation of long-term data and (ii) method for on-site evaluation of thermal expansion coefficient. These methods resulted from emerged necessity to cleanse the data and establish accurate relationship between strain and temperature.

The methods are universally applicable to a wide range of existing and new beam bridges, but also to other types of civil structures and infrastructure. They are not material dependent and do not require alteration of traffic (e.g., no need to interrupt the traffic, to perform additional tests, etc.).

The created methods have potential to help avoid disruptive closures, costly repairs, and catastrophic structural failures of bridges, while also ensuring their on-going reliability through an efficient monitoring and health assessment. Besides the applications in civil engineering, the methods have potential to be applied in mechanical engineering too (e.g., aeronautical and naval structures). Consequently, the methods may result in a profound societal impact by addressing public safety, minimizing economic disruption, and mitigating environmental damage.

A widespread use of the methods based on strain, temperature and displacement sensors may create new job positions and set prevalence of the U.S. products and know-how in the world. Extensive implementation of TD-SHM on typical infrastructure will deliver precious basis for informed decision making and reinforce the U.S. competence in the field of SHM.

To conduct this research, women in engineering and research were engaged through undergraduate and graduate student projects. The research outcomes are merged in Civil Engineering undergraduate and graduate courses at Princeton University, and graduate students were involved in undergraduate teaching activities. Particular attention was given to make sure that students experienced the interdisciplinary nature of the research, which combined structural engineering, metrology, and statistical analysis.

Dissemination to academic and industrial communities, as well as infrastructure authorities, is carried out by publishing papers, presenting posters, delivering seminars, and through live demonstrations on the Streicker Bridge on Princeton University campus.
